text: we've just finished our final bit of
filming and we're heading back to the
hotel now throughout this week I've had
quite a lot of people tweeting and
getting in touch online asking how our
team keeping ourselves safe well it's a
really long process actually and it
started many weeks ago back in London
with a very long risk assessments on
that we filled in all our details we
talked about every single part of our
plan and we assessed the risk involved
in all of it we also came out here with
a biohazard expert named Matt he has
been monitoring everything we're doing
make sure we're staying safe and he's
got lots of disinfectant gloves he's got
all our biohazard suits with him so he's
a really key part of making sure this
story gets out the way Ebola is
transmitted is through clothes body
contact it's spread spread through body
fluids so we make sure that we keep our
hands to ourselves the instinct is when
we meet people and we're going to
interview especially support our hands
out and give them a handshake but
obviously here we can't do that people
understand that something here called
the Ebola handshake where you sort of
pat your chest instead of shaking hands
the other thing is we carry around a
little bottle of this disinfectant
everywhere we go it clips onto our
trousers and we are constantly
disinfecting
when we're getting out of the car when
we go out and about we disinfect before
we go out and about we disinfect when we
get back into the car including spraying
our shoes before we get back in so if
you go in the office I would wash your
hands any way out and I just wouldn't
touch things but it's in theory
completely safe office so if you go in
there just you know she hands itself and
it should be complete clean as you'll
see that's a green zone you'll see
orange tape on the door that shows that
it's kind of a medium risk zone so I'll
go in there but you shouldn't want I get
dressed in sleepy and then beyond that
the red zone which I'll walk into but
you shouldn't you know you won't even
return so you shouldn't go anywhere near
the red zone we're just in the green
zone at the moment here we are perfectly
safe but it's just through here that
things are much more dangerous this is
the amber zone this is where medics get
themself suited up and beyond there is
the red zone that is where suspected
Ebola patients are I related one of the
other more high-risk things we did was
we went to an Ebola graveyard and for
that bit of filming we wore full white
plastic body suits they were completely
sealed
we had gloves on we had goggles on and
that was to make sure that anything we
picked up even on our shoes we had
plastic coverings anything we picked up
wouldn't come with us when we went home
we're boiling hot we're sweating in
these things we haven't been in them for
more than half an hour I've got sweat
coming down and gathering in my goggles
I've got sweat gathering in this mouth
I just want to get this
Mack was on hand to cut us out of those
suits he cut them from behind and pulled
them off us in a very specific way he
also had to take our gloves off in a
very specific way taking them off what
are they for telling them inside out and
putting them all into a special
biohazard yellow bag I've done a great
deal to mitigate the risks but in the
end we are reporting from the world's
biggest ever outbreak of Ebola
I've been asked quite a few times by
lots of people online and on Facebook
and Twitter about why we put ourselves
in this sort of risk and having been out
on the ground we've spoken to people
we've spoken to the doctors and nurses
dealing with this outbreak we've spoken
to the aid agencies and the normal
Sierra Leoneans just out on the street
having to live with this killer virus
and what is so important is that the
world hears about their plight and that
is why we're here
we're here to tell their story
